measured_by: single 7-point Likert item: "How likely do you think you are to win a prize while playing Power 5?"
justification: The article states: "participants' perceived likelihood of winning a prize while playing Power 5 was assessed with the following item: 'How likely do you think you are to win a prize while playing Power 5?' Participants responded ... using a 7-point scale".
construct: Perceived likelihood of winning a prize

measured_by: single 7-point Likert item: "How excited would you be to play Power 5?"
justification: Under Excitement the authors note: "Participants reported their excitement to play Power 5 by responding to the question 'How excited would you be to play Power 5?' ... using a scale that ranged from 1 (Not at all excited) to 7 (Extremely excited)."

measured_by: single 7-point Likert item: "Please indicate your urge to gamble on Power 5"
justification: The Materials section says: "Participants' urge to gamble was assessed with the item: 'Please indicate your urge to gamble on Power 5.' Responses ... were provided using a scale that ranged from 1 (No urge to gamble) to 7 (Strong urge to gamble)."

measured_by: scenario question asking number of Power 5 cards (0–10) participants would purchase
justification: The article explains: "We assessed participants' hypothetical card purchasing behaviour by presenting them with the scenario... 'how many Power 5 cards would you like to purchase?' ... participants indicated how many ... up to a maximum of ten."

measured_by: Problem Gambling Severity Index (PGSI) – 9-item subscale of the CPGI
justification: It states: "The Problem Gambling Severity Index (PGSI) ... provides a reliable and valid measure of problem gambling symptomatology. Participants completed 9 items ... summed to create an overall PGSI score."
The text notes: "Cognitive Reflection Test (CRT; Frederick, 2005) ... Participants were presented with four CRT items ... resulting in a CRT score for each participant."

measured_by: 3-item Numeracy Scale (Schwartz et al., 1997; Weller et al., 2013)
justification: Materials section: "We administered three numeracy scale items (Schwartz et al., 1997; Weller et al., 2013) ... We calculated a numeracy score ... which reflected the number of correct responses."

measured_by: free-entry ratio estimates for small ($25), medium ($250) and large ($100,000) prizes
justification: Experiment 2 adds: "participants concluded Experiment 2 by completing three items in which they estimated their odds of winning a small ($25), medium ($250), and large ($100,000) prize while playing Power 5. These estimates were provided in a free-entry text box in the form of a ratio."
construct: Perceived odds of winning specific prizes

measured_by: single self-report frequency item (1 = Have not played to 6 = Played 24 or more times)
justification: Exploratory analyses table note: "Scratch Card Frequency represents participants' self-reported scratch card gambling frequency in the past 12 months," and response options ranged from 1 (Have not played) to 6 (Played 24 or more times).
